name: Bass, Lee M.
title: President
political_donations: Republican donor; Bush Pioneer (2000 presidential campaign, bundled contributions totaling $78,427); donated to George W. Bush, George Allen, Phil Gramm, John McCain, Kay Bailey Hutchison, and Rick Perry ($159,760); Lee M Bass Inc 2024 cycle contributions totaled $1,240,402
ngos: Sid W. Richardson Foundation (board); The Peregrine Fund (Chairman Emeritus); International Rhino Foundation (founding director); Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth (Chairman Emeritus of Board); Lee and Ramona Bass Foundation (founder); Texas Parks and Wildlife Commission (commissioner 1989-2001, chairman 1995-2001)
notes: Fort Worth billionaire; great-great-nephew of oil baron Sid Richardson; Bass family sold oil interests to ExxonMobil in 2017 for ~$6.6 billion; Yale University alumnus (1979) and Wharton MBA (1982); donated $20 million to Yale in 1991 for a Western civilization program — gift was returned by Yale in 1995 due to dispute over faculty control; net worth estimated at $2.24 billion as of 2025

name: Bulley, Allan E. III
title: Chairman & CEO
notes: Fourth generation to lead Bulley & Andrews, a Chicago-based regional construction firm founded in 1891; Yale University graduate; MBA from Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern University

name: Bulley, Allan E. Jr.
title: Executive Chairman
ngos: Museum of Science & Industry, Chicago (Buildings & Grounds Committee Chairman); DePaul University School of Music (Pro Musica Award honoree 2018)
notes: Third generation to lead Bulley & Andrews; joined the firm in 1956; succeeded his father as President in 1970; B.S. in Civil Engineering from Brown University

name: Char, Devron H.
employer: Tumori Foundation; California Pacific Medical Center
title: Director and President (Tumori Foundation); Ophthalmologist
ngos: Tumori Foundation (Director and President); Eye Cancer Foundation
notes: Pioneer ophthalmologist specializing in ocular oncology — eyelid, orbital, conjunctival, and intraocular cancers; MD from University of Minnesota (1970); residency at UCSF Medical Center; fellowship at the National Cancer Institute; Clinical Professor at Stanford University and UCSF; speaks French, German, and Spanish; practice at California Pacific Medical Center Van Ness Campus, San Francisco

name: Diethelm, Markus U.
title: Co-Chairman
ngos: American Swiss Foundation (Co-Chairman); Swiss Finance Institute (Vice Chairman); Musée International de la Croix-Rouge et du Croissant-Rouge (Director, since 2014)
notes: Swiss attorney and banking executive; former Group General Counsel and Executive Board member of UBS AG (2008-2021) and Credit Suisse AG (2022-2023); departed Credit Suisse/UBS following the emergency UBS takeover of Credit Suisse in 2023; lic.iur. from University of Zurich; JSD from Stanford Law School; admitted to bar in Zurich, Geneva, and New York; winner of General Counsel of the Year at 2016 Global Counsel Awards; former associate at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison and Shearman & Sterling in New York; career began at Bär & Karrer, Zurich (1983)

name: Folger, Lee Merritt
title: Chairman of the Board
ngos: American Red Cross, District of Columbia chapter (Chairman 1971-1977); American Red Cross National Board of Governors (member 1976-1982); Brookings Institution (donor); Center for Strategic and International Studies (donor); Peterson Institute for International Economics (donor)
notes: American investment company executive; A.B. from Harvard University (1956); joined Folger Nolan Fleming Douglas, an independent Washington D.C.-based investment firm founded in 1889, in the late 1950s; father John Folger was U.S. Ambassador to Belgium and chairman of the Republican National Finance Committee

name: Goodyear, James Owsley
notes: Property owner in San Francisco, CA (145 Presidio Avenue)

name: Hale, Prentis C. III
title: General Partner
notes: San Francisco venture capitalist; born April 22, 1942; Yale University BA (1964), Stanford University MBA (1966); ran angel investing group funding startups in technology and oil and gas; came from prominent San Francisco family — father Prentis Cobb Hale Jr. was chairman of Carter Hawley Hale stores; earlier career at Mackay Shields Finance, Bryan & Edwards, and Hambrecht & Quist in San Francisco; noted by Marquis Who's Who as venture capitalist; died May 30, 2022 in Sheridan, Oregon

name: Humphrey, G. Watts Jr.
title: President
ngos: University of Pittsburgh (Trustee and Chairman of Board of Trustees); Centre College (Trustee, re-elected); Yale University Development Board (member); Pittsburgh Symphony Society (Director); Sewickley Academy (Vice Chair); Shaker Village of Pleasant Hill (Vice Chairman and Trustee); Churchill Downs (Director Emeritus)
notes: Pittsburgh businessman and prominent thoroughbred horse owner and breeder; born June 12, 1944 in Cleveland, Ohio; Yale BA; Harvard Business School MBA; also Chairman and CEO of International Plastics Equipment Group, Inc. and Centria (metal building exteriors); formerly held senior positions at National Steel Corporation; grandfather George M. Humphrey served as Secretary of the Treasury under President Eisenhower; partner in the St. Louis Cardinals MLB team; leading Thoroughbred owner at Keeneland Race Course fall meeting (2011)

name: Johnson, Peter A.
title: Partner
notes: San Francisco-based wealth management professional; formerly President, CEO, and Portfolio Manager at Ashfield Capital Partners (joined 1994); Ashfield merged with Cerity Partners; served on Ashfield's Board of Managers

name: Marquardt, David F.
title: Co-Founder and General Partner
ngos: Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton (Trustee); Western Association of Venture Capitalists (past President); National Venture Capital Association (past Director)
notes: Pioneering venture capitalist; born February 1, 1949; co-founded Technology Venture Investors (TVI) in 1980 — was the sole venture capital investor in Microsoft, owning 6.2% of Microsoft stock at its 1986 IPO; served on Microsoft board of directors 1981-2014; co-founded August Capital in 1995; served on 40+ boards including Microsoft, Sun Microsystems, Seagate, Adaptec; BSME from Columbia University (1973); MBA from Stanford University (1979)

name: McCormack, Robert C.
title: Advisory Director
notes: Former U.S. government defense official; served as Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Production Support (1987-1988), Deputy Under Secretary of Defense for Industrial and International Programs (1988-1990), and Assistant Secretary of the Navy (Financial Management and Comptroller) (1990-1993); co-founded venture capital firm Trident Capital after leaving government; Managing Director of Trident Capital until 2005, then Advisory Director; board service includes DeVry Inc., Illinois Tool Works, MeadWestvaco, Northern Trust Corporation, MapQuest, and PGi; BA from University of North Carolina (1962); served in U.S. Navy 1962-1966; MBA from University of Chicago (1968)

name: McGettigan, Charles C.
title: Managing Director
notes: San Francisco investment banker; born March 28, 1945; founded McGettigan & Wick Co., Inc. in 1988 (boutique investment banking and private equity); also founded Proactive Investment Managers LP in 1991 (General Partner); previously Senior Vice President at Dillon, Read & Co. and Principal-Corporate Finance at Hambrecht & Quist; appointed Non-executive Chairman of Insured Aircraft Title Service, Inc. (2015); MBA from University of Pennsylvania (Wharton); undergraduate degree from Georgetown University

name: Nouri, Michael
title: Actor
notes: American screen and stage actor; born December 9, 1945 in Washington D.C.; known for starring role as Nick Hurley in Flashdance (1983), one of the highest-grossing films of that year; television roles include Dr. Neil Roberts on The O.C., Phil Grey on Damages, Caleb Cortlandt on All My Children, Eli David in NCIS, and Bob Schwartz on Yellowstone; nominated for a Daytime Emmy Award for Search for Tomorrow; father was an Iraqi immigrant who became a writer for Stars and Stripes and The New Yorker

name: Osthimer, Charles E. III
title: Counsel
notes: San Francisco civil litigation defense attorney; practice areas include aviation, products liability, toxic torts, professional errors and omissions, and business/commercial matters; J.D. from UC Hastings College of the Law; previously Shareholder at Wright, Robinson, Osthimer & Tatum; earlier career at Bronson, Bronson & McKinnon (Associate to Partner); also served as Senior Legal Counsel at Lankford Crawford Moreno & Ostertag

name: Parsky, Gerald L.
title: Chairman
political_donations: Made 6 contributions totaling $98,595 to the Republican National Committee between 1992 and June 2012; personally gave $200,000 to the RNC; chaired George W. Bush's California presidential campaigns in 2000 and 2004; major Republican bundler and fundraiser; chaired 1996 Republican National Convention Host Committee in San Diego
ngos: Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation and Institute (Board of Trustees); RAND Corporation (Board of Trustees); Hoover Institution (fellow); Salk Institute (Trustee); George Bush Presidential Library Foundation (Trustee); University of California Board of Regents (member and Chairman, 1996-2008); Center for the Study of the Presidency & Congress (Board Member); PPIC (Board Member)
notes: Former U.S. Assistant Secretary of the Treasury under Presidents Nixon and Ford (1974-1977) — youngest ever to hold that position; responsible for capital markets policy and all international affairs including trade, monetary policy, investment, and energy policy; Time magazine called him 'Treasury's Wunderkind'; Senior Partner at Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher (1977-1992); founded Aurora Capital Group in 1992, managing over $2 billion in private equity; J.D. from University of Virginia School of Law (1968); strong California Republican political figure; born 1942

name: Pelkan, John R.
title: Owner / Vineyard Operator
notes: California winemaker and viticulturist; owns Pelkan Ranch in Knights Valley, Sonoma County (66.7 acres, 21.31 planted acres), acquired 1985; active in Sonoma and Napa county grape-growing communities; vineyard grows Cabernet Franc, Cabernet Sauvignon, Grenache, Syrah, and Sauvignon Blanc; grapes from his Cabernet Franc vines were used in the Trinitas Cellars 2012 wine served to Pope Francis; married Carolyn Pelkan in 1960; died 2024 (per Legacy.com obituary)

name: Read, J. Leighton M.D.
title: Venture Partner
ngos: BioVentures for Global Health (BVGH) (Board of Directors); BeneTech Initiative (Trustee/Director); UC Berkeley Foundation and School of Public Health Council (member); Santa Fe Institute (Trustee/Director)
notes: Serial biotech entrepreneur and venture investor; BS from Rice University; MD from University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio; internal medicine training at Duke and Peter Bent Brigham Hospital/Harvard Medical School and School of Public Health; co-founded Affymax NV (spun out Affymetrix and Maxygen); founded Aviron, developer of FluMist intranasal influenza vaccine — served as Chairman and CEO until 1999, until MedImmune acquisition in 2002; Managing Director of Alloy Ventures 2000-2008; EY Northern California Entrepreneur of the Year award winner; co-inventor of technology underlying the Affymetrix GeneChip

name: Redlich, C. R. Jr.
title: Founder and Former Chairman
ngos: Gladstone Institutes (Board of Trustees); Hoover Institution (Board of Overseers); Hudson Institute (Chairman's Advisory Board); Healing Healthcare (founder, nonprofit)
notes: Retired shipping executive; during his tenure Marine Terminals Corporation (founded by the Horsman/Redlich family in 1931) became the largest contract stevedore and ocean terminal operator in the United States; served as President and Chairman of the Board of Marine Terminals Corporation; later served as Chairman of Embarcadero Systems and Director of Embarcadero Insurance; founded Healing Healthcare, a nonprofit aimed at transforming U.S. healthcare into a more cost-effective and accessible system; purchased a $32 million mansion in Nashville in 2022, setting a Tennessee record

name: Riley, Warren B. Jr.
title: Executive Consultant (Security, Policing, Emergency Response Management)
notes: Former Superintendent of the New Orleans Police Department (September 2005 - May 2010); promoted from Assistant Superintendent just 30 days after Hurricane Katrina; led NOPD through the chaotic post-Katrina period; joined NOPD in 1981; later served as Adjunct Professor at Southern University at New Orleans (Master's program in Criminal Justice, since 2005) and Director of Campus Police at Delgado Community College (since March 2020); worked as a federal coordinating officer for FEMA; sued Mayor LaToya Cantrell after a promised homeland security director job was withdrawn; subject of controversy for handling of Danziger Bridge and other post-Katrina incidents

name: Seeligson, Arthur A. III
title: Principal / Registered Agent
notes: Texas oil and gas operator; son of Arthur A. Seeligson Jr. (1920-2001), oilman, rancher, and thoroughbred racehorse owner who was fabulously wealthy from royalty interests in Jim Wells County, Texas; the Seeligson family has deep roots in the Texas oil industry dating to the 1930s (Seeligson oil field); associated with Seeligson Oil Co. and Seeligson Ranch in San Antonio area; holds mineral interests in Houston, TX

name: Thieriot, Peter E.
title: Managing Member
notes: Great-grandson of San Francisco Chronicle co-founder M.H. de Young; spent 15 years in publishing, mostly as Vice President of San Francisco Newspaper Printing Company; held multiple roles for The Chronicle Publishing Company including President, Vice President, Publisher, and Station Manager for newspapers and television stations; Board of Riverbend Industries (since 2001); became a rancher and co-owner of thebuffaloguys.com, the country's largest buffalo meat purveyor; served as director or trustee for numerous cultural, civic, and nonprofit organizations
